Islands in minor-closed classes. I. Bounded treewidth and separators

ZdenÄ›k DvoÅ™Ã¡k
Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic. E-mail: rakdver@iuuk.mff.cuni.cz. Supported by project 17-04611S (Ramsey-like aspects of graph coloring) of Czech Science Foundation. â€ƒâ€ƒ Sergey Norin Department of Mathematics and Statistics, McGill University. Abstract

The clustered chromatic number of a graph class is the minimum integer tğ‘¡t such that for some Cğ¶C the vertices of every graph in the class can be colored in tğ‘¡t colors so that every monochromatic component has size at most Cğ¶C. We show that the clustered chromatic number of the class of graphs embeddable on a given surface is four, proving the conjecture of Esperet and Ochem. Additionally, we study the list version of the concept and characterize the minor-closed classes of graphs of bounded treewidth with given clustered list chromatic number. We further strengthen the above results to solve some extremal problems on bootstrap percolation of minor-closed classes.

Rather than working with the clustered (list) chromatic number, we bound a different parameter which dominates it. The coloring number colâ€‹(G)colğº\text{col}(G) of a graph GğºG is the smallest integer tğ‘¡t such that every non-empty subgraph of GğºG contains a vertex of degree less than tğ‘¡t. A standard greedy argument shows that Ï‡â€‹(G)â‰¤colâ€‹(G)ğœ’ğºcolğº\chi(G)\leq\text{col}(G). Let us now introduce a similar notion for clustered coloring, first defined by Esperet and OchemÂ [11]. For every integer Câ‰¥1ğ¶1C\geq 1, every graph GğºG satisfies Ï‡Clâ€‹(G)â‰¤colCâ€‹(G)subscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ‘™ğ¶ğºsubscriptcolğ¶ğº\chi^{l}_{C}(G)\leq\text{col}_{C}(G).

In the next section we state our main results and present several applications, including proofs of two conjectures of Esperet and Ochem. We prove our two main results in SectionsÂ 3 andÂ 4.

Finally, let us discuss a relationship to another concept, bootstrap percolation. Consider the following process on a graph GğºG for some integer tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0. Let vertices of some set A0âŠ†Vâ€‹(G)subscriptğ´0ğ‘‰ğºA_{0}\subseteq V(G) be marked active. If there exists an inactive vertex vğ‘£v in GğºG with at least tğ‘¡t active neighbors, vğ‘£v becomes active. We repeat this procedure until there are no more inactive vertices with at least tğ‘¡t active neighbors. If at the end, all vertices of GğºG are active, we say that the set A0subscriptğ´0A_{0} tğ‘¡t-percolates. Bootstrap percolation was introduced by Chalupa, Leath and ReichÂ [5] as a simplification of existing models of ferromagnetism. Extremal problems for bootstrap percolation, similar to the ones we consider in this paper, were studied for very structured graph families e.g. inÂ [4, 20].

For Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, we say that a graph GğºG is Îµğœ€\varepsilon-resistant to tğ‘¡t-percolation if no set of at most Îµâ€‹|Vâ€‹(G)|ğœ€ğ‘‰ğº\varepsilon|V(G)| vertices of GğºG tğ‘¡t-percolates. For a class of graphs ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G}, let us define the percolation threshold pâ€‹(ğ’¢)ğ‘ğ’¢p({\cal G}) of ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} to be the minimum integer tğ‘¡t such that for some Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, all non-null graphs in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} are Îµğœ€\varepsilon-resistant to tğ‘¡t-percolation (pâ€‹(ğ’¢)=âˆğ‘ğ’¢p({\cal G})=\infty if no such tğ‘¡t exists). Clearly, all graphs in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} are also Îµğœ€\varepsilon-resistant to tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}-percolation for every tâ€²â‰¥tsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘¡t^{\prime}\geq t.

How to show that a class is percolation resistant? Observe that a set tğ‘¡t-percolates if and only if no tğ‘¡t-island is contained in its complement. If a graph GğºG contains more than Îµâ€‹|Vâ€‹(G)|ğœ€ğ‘‰ğº\varepsilon|V(G)| pairwise disjoint tğ‘¡t-islands, then each set of size at most Îµâ€‹|Vâ€‹(G)|ğœ€ğ‘‰ğº\varepsilon|V(G)| is disjoint from at least one of them, and thus it does not tğ‘¡t-percolate. Hence, the following notion gives an upper bound to the percolation threshold. Let the pervasive clustered coloring number pcolâ‹†â€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptpcolâ‹†ğ’¢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G}) denote the minimum integer tğ‘¡t such that for some Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, each graph Gâˆˆğ’¢ğºğ’¢G\in{\cal G} contains at least Îµâ€‹|Vâ€‹(G)|ğœ€ğ‘‰ğº\varepsilon|V(G)| pairwise disjoint tğ‘¡t-islands (pcolâ‹†â€‹(ğ’¢)=âˆsubscriptpcolâ‹†ğ’¢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})=\infty if no such tğ‘¡t exists).

If GğºG contains linearly many pairwise disjoint tğ‘¡t-islands, some of them must have constant size. Hence, for a subgraph-closed class ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} we have inequalities pcolâ‹†â€‹(ğ’¢)â‰¥pâ€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptpcolâ‹†ğ’¢ğ‘ğ’¢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})\geq p({\cal G}) and pcolâ‹†â€‹(ğ’¢)â‰¥colâ‹†â€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptpcolâ‹†ğ’¢subscriptcolâ‹†ğ’¢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})\geq\text{col}_{\star}({\cal G}). In general, percolation threshold may be smaller than the clustered coloring number; e.g., for tâ‰¥3ğ‘¡3t\geq 3 the class of graphs GğºG with maximum degree at most tğ‘¡t and girth Î©â€‹(logâ¡(|Vâ€‹(G)|))Î©ğ‘‰ğº\Omega(\log(|V(G)|)) has clustered coloring number tğ‘¡t (since in tğ‘¡t-regular graphs in the class, all (tâˆ’1)ğ‘¡1(t-1)-islands must contain cycles) but all the graphs in this class are (tâˆ’2)/(2â€‹tâˆ’2)ğ‘¡22ğ‘¡2(t-2)/(2t-2)-resistant to (tâˆ’1)ğ‘¡1(t-1)-percolation (since the complements of sets of size at most tâˆ’22â€‹tâˆ’2â€‹|Vâ€‹(G)|ğ‘¡22ğ‘¡2ğ‘‰ğº\tfrac{t-2}{2t-2}|V(G)| contain a vertex of degree at most tâˆ’2ğ‘¡2t-2, or two vertices of degree tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1 joined by a path, or a cycle, forming a (tâˆ’1)ğ‘¡1(t-1)-island).

However, in SectionÂ 3 we prove the following.

Theorem 16.

Let ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} be a class of graphs closed under taking subgraphs, such that ğ’¢âŠ†ğ’³â€‹(H)ğ’¢ğ’³ğ»{\cal G}\subseteq\mathcal{X}(H) for some graph Hğ»H. Then pcolâ‹†â€‹(ğ’¢)=pâ€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptpcolâ‹†ğ’¢ğ‘ğ’¢\text{pcol}_{\star}({\cal G})=p({\cal G}).

4 Clustered chromatic number of classes of bounded treewidth

We start by introducing the necessary concepts. For sets A,Bğ´ğµA,B of vertices of a graph of the same size kğ‘˜k, an Aâˆ’Bğ´ğµA-B linkage is a set of kğ‘˜k pairwise vertex-disjoint paths with one end in Ağ´A and the other end in BğµB.

We now show how to transform a tree decomposition of large order and bounded width into a path decomposition of large order and bounded adhesion, and then to clean it up, making it linked, appearance-universal, and with large interiors. The techniques to do so are standard and appear e.g. inÂ [14]; we give brief arguments here to adjust for minor technical details and notational differences.

Observation 24.

A coarsening of a proper decomposition is proper. A coarsening of a linked decomposition is linked. A coarsening of a decomposition of adhesion pğ‘p has adhesion at most pğ‘p. A coarsening of an appearance-universal decomposition is appearance-universal; furthermore, if an appearance-universal decomposition has large interiors, then its coarsening has large interiors.

5 Concluding remarks

In this paper we studied improper colorings of minor-closed graph classes, where we used the size of the maximum monochromatic component as a measure of impropriety. One can attempt building a similar theory for other impropriety measures as follows. We say that a graph parameter fğ‘“f with values in â„+âˆª{+âˆ}subscriptâ„\mathbb{R}_{+}\cup\{+\infty\} is connected if for a disconnected graph GğºG with components G1,G2,â€¦,Gksubscriptğº1subscriptğº2â€¦subscriptğºğ‘˜G_{1},G_{2},\ldots,G_{k} we have fâ€‹(G)=max1â‰¤iâ‰¤kâ¡fâ€‹(Gi)ğ‘“ğºsubscript1ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘“subscriptğºğ‘–f(G)=\max_{1\leq i\leq k}f(G_{i}).

Let fğ‘“f be a connected monotone graph parameter. The fğ‘“f-chromatic number Ï‡fâ€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptğœ’ğ‘“ğ’¢\chi_{f}({\cal G}) of a graph class GğºG as the minimum tğ‘¡t such that there exists real Cğ¶C satisfying the following. For every Gâˆˆğ’¢ğºğ’¢G\in\mathcal{G} there exists a partition V1,â€¦,Vtsubscriptğ‘‰1â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡V_{1},\ldots,V_{t} of Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G) so that fâ€‹(Gâ€‹[Vi])â‰¤Cğ‘“ğºdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–ğ¶f(G[V_{i}])\leq C for every 1â‰¤iâ‰¤t1ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\leq i\leq t. For example, TheoremÂ 9 implies that Ï‡twâ€‹(ğ’¢)â‰¤2subscriptğœ’twğ’¢2\chi_{\operatorname{tw}}({\cal G})\leq 2 for every minor-closed class ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G}.

One can also define the fğ‘“f-list chromatic number Ï‡flâ€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ‘™ğ‘“ğ’¢\chi^{l}_{f}({\cal G}) and the fğ‘“f-coloring number colfâ€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptcolğ‘“ğ’¢\text{col}_{f}({\cal G}) of a graph class GğºG analogously to the clustered list chromatic and coloring numbers. The inequalities colfâ€‹(ğ’¢)â‰¥Ï‡flâ€‹(ğ’¢)â‰¥Ï‡fâ€‹(ğ’¢)subscriptcolğ‘“ğ’¢subscriptsuperscriptğœ’ğ‘™ğ‘“ğ’¢subscriptğœ’ğ‘“ğ’¢\text{col}_{f}(\mathcal{G})\geq\chi^{l}_{f}(\mathcal{G})\geq\chi_{f}(\mathcal{G}) hold for any choice of fğ‘“f.
